clinical_study.brief_title: Temperature Measurement in Post-Anesthesia Care Units
clinical_study.official_title: Accuracy of Temperature Measurement in Post-Anesthesia Care Units

brief_summary.textblock: This study will evaluate the accuracy of several thermometers and temperature changes during surgery and immediately after surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
Several measurements of temperature will be taken at 30 minute intervals during surgery under general anesthesia and in the post operative care unit. Measurements will be taken as follows:
- esophagus using an internal stethoscope
- urinary bladder using a catheter
- ear canal
- skin of the forehead using adhesive devices(4 thermometers)
- axilla ("armpit") using adhesive devices(2 thermometers)
- mouth
- skin of the upper chest

primary_outcome.measure: To determine the accuracy of various temperature-monitoring methods and sites suitable for Post Anesthesia Care Unit use.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Discharge from Post Anesthesia Care Unit

secondary_outcome.measure: To quantify the core temperature changes that occur during transport from the Operating Room to the PostAnesthesia Care Unit.

arm_group.description: Patients undergoing laparoscopic surgery requiring general anesthesia and a bladder catheter.

intervention.description: Temperature readings every 30 minutes during and post surgery using internal stethoscope, catheter and adhesive patches/electronic thermometer.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- 18 to 80 years of age
- American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status of 1-3
- laparoscopic surgery of the abdomen or pelvis that is expected to require general endotracheal anesthesia and insertion of a Foley catheter expected to be in place for at least one hour after surgery
Exclusion Criteria:
- under 18 or over 80 years of age
- pre-existing nasogastric tube
- require bispectral index monitoring
- upper esophageal disease
- forehead rash or infection, oral infection or trauma, or ear infection or drainage
